title: 115_s992
content: The Act titled "Veteran Overmedication Prevention Act of 2017" mandates an independent review by the Department of Veterans Affairs of certain veteran suicides. The "Veteran Overmedication Prevention Act of 2017" requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to collaborate with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to review the suicides of covered veterans over a five-year period, regardless of CDC reporting. The review will include the total number of veteran suicides during this period. The "Veteran Overmedication Prevention Act of 2017" mandates a review of covered veterans' deaths by violent or accidental means over a five-year period. It also requires a detailed description of the deceased veterans, including age, gender, race, and ethnicity, along with a list of prescribed medications and substances found in toxicology reports. The summary of medical diagnoses by physicians for covered veterans prescribed medications for PTSD, TBI, military sexual trauma, and anxiety/depressive disorders. It also includes the number of instances where veterans were on multiple medications concurrently. The Department provides programs for veterans with PTSD, TBI, military sexual trauma, anxiety, and depressive disorders. The percentage of veterans not taking prescribed medication is also monitored. The Department monitors the percentage of veterans who received non-medication first-line treatment for PTSD, TBI, military sexual trauma, anxiety, and depressive disorders, and the subsequent prescribing of medication if the initial treatment was ineffective. The Department determines clinical practice guidelines for medication prescribing, measures pain scores systematically, evaluates the impact on veterans on multiple medications, and maintains appropriate staffing levels for mental health. The Department aims to maintain appropriate staffing levels for mental health professionals, including mental health counselors and marriage and family therapists, by addressing impediments and increasing their representation in the workforce. The Department aims to assess the behavioral health workforce, including eligibility criteria and participation in training programs. The Department assesses hiring guidelines for mental health counselors and therapists, identifies gaps in mental health professional supply, and determines staffing ratios. The Secretary collaborates with the Office of Personnel Management to establish an occupational series for mental health professionals. The Department is creating an occupational series for mental health counselors and marriage and family therapists, ensuring professional standards boards are comprised of these professionals. The curr_chunk discusses the percentage of covered veterans with combat experience or trauma related to combat, identification of medical facilities with high prescription and suicide rates for veterans, and analysis of Department programs collaborating with State Medicaid agencies and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. An analysis of Department staff checking State prescription drug monitoring programs before prescribing medications to veterans, coordinating with external prescribers to prevent overprescribing, and taking action when veterans are overprescribed. Additionally, collaboration between Department medical centers and medical examiners' offices to determine veteran mortality and cause of death is examined. An assessment of veteran death certificate data collection and reporting practices by the Department of Veterans Affairs, with recommendations for improving veteran safety and well-being. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs ensures data compilation in a manner allowing analysis across all fields to inform clinical practice guidelines. Data on covered veterans is compiled separately and disaggregated by year. The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine will review data on covered veterans and submit a report to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 180 days. The Secretary will then report the results to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs and make it publicly available. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "black box warning," "covered veteran," "first-line treatment," and "State." These definitions clarify the meanings of these terms within the context of the prescription drug labeling and veteran healthcare system.
